'''Asmaa Mahfouz''' ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø³ÙØ§Ø¡ ÙØ­ÙÙØ¸}}, {{IPA-arz|ÊÃ¦sËmÃ¦ËÊ mÉÄ§ËfuËz, ËÊÃ¦smÃ¦-|pron}}, born February 1, 1985) is an Egyptian activist and one of the founders of the [[April 6 Youth Movement]].<ref name='NYT110202'>{{cite news | first = Mona | last = El-Naggar | title = Equal rights takes to the barricades | date = February 1, 2011 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2011-02-06}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | first = Essam | last = Fadl | title = A talk with Egyptian activist Asmaa Mahfouz | date = February 7, 2011 | url = http://aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=24073 | work = Asharq Al-Awsat | accessdate = 2011-02-07}}</ref> She has been credited by journalist [[Mona Eltahawy]] and others with helping to spark mass uprising through her video blog posted one week before the start of the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egyptian revolution of 2011]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date = February 4, 2011 | work = National Public Radio | format = transcript | accessdate = 2011-02-06}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | title = Revolutionary blogger Asma threatened | date = February 5, 2011 | url = http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/revolutionary-blogger-asma-threatened-1.757171 | work = Gulf News | accessdate = 2011-02-06}}</ref>
'''Asmaa Mahfouz''' ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø³ÙØ§Ø¡ ÙØ­ÙÙØ¸}}, {{IPA-arz|ÊÃ¦sËmÃ¦ËÊ mÉÄ§ËfuËz, ËÊÃ¦smÃ¦-|pron}}, born February 1, 1985) is an Egyptian activist and one of the founders of the [[April 6 Youth Movement]].<ref name='NYT110202'>{{cite news | first = Mona | last = El-Naggar | title = Equal rights takes to the barricades | date = February 1, 2011 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2011-02-06}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | first = Essam | last = Fadl | title = A talk with Egyptian activist Asmaa Mahfouz | date = February 7, 2011 | url = http://aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=24073 | work = Asharq Al-Awsat | accessdate = 2011-02-07}}</ref> She has been credited by journalist [[Mona Eltahawy]] and others with helping to spark mass uprising through her video blog posted one week before the start of the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egyptian revolution of 2011]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date = February 4, 2011 | work = National Public Radio | format = transcript | accessdate = 2011-02-06}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | title = Revolutionary blogger Asma threatened | date = February 5, 2011 | url = http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/revolutionary-blogger-asma-threatened-1.757171 | work = Gulf News | accessdate = 2011-02-06}}</ref>
  +   +
==Overview==
  +   +
Asmaa Mahfouz is one of the founders of the [[Egyptian]] [[April 6 Youth Movement]]<ref>http://www.straight.com/article-371120/vancouver/video-asmaa-mahfouzs-post-helped-kickstart-egypt-uprising</ref><ref>http://www.memritv.org/clip/en/2785.htm</ref>
  +   +
==Early life==
  +   +
She was born in [[Egypt]] and is of Egyptian [[Arab]] descent. Ms. Mahfouz was born in 1985<ref>http://www.straight.com/article-371120/vancouver/video-asmaa-mahfouzs-post-helped-kickstart-egypt-uprising</ref>, graduated from the business management school of the [[American University in Cairo]].<ref>{{cite news | first = Mona | last = El-Naggar | title = Equal Rights Takes to the Barricades | date = February 1, 2011 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2011-02-06}}</ref> She worked as an [[accountant]] at [[Al Shaimaa export and import firm]] until her job was suspended due to her political activity in the 2011 protests<ref>http://www.linkedin.com/pub/dir/Asmaa/Mahfouz</ref>.
  +   +
==2008 protests==
  +   +
Upon graduation, Mahfouz emerged as an activist on social media pages throughout [[Egypt]]<ref>http://www.memritv.org/clip/en/2785.htm</ref>. In 2008, Mahfouz and other activists connected with the April 6 Movement used the internet to mobilize support for a general strike. As a result, Mahfouz and her family were subjected to harassment by Egyptian security forces.
  +   +
==January 2011 uprising in Egypt==
  +   +
Asmaa Mahfouz is considered one of the most important symbols of the January 2011 uprising in [[Egypt]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hui |first=Stephen |url=http://www.straight.com/article-371120/vancouver/video-asmaa-mahfouzs-post-helped-kickstart-egypt-uprising |title=Video: Asmaa Mahfouz's post helped kick-start Egypt uprising |publisher=Straight.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref> Using [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]] <ref>[-://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SgjIgMdsEuk] </ref> and a famous [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SgjIgMdsEuk YouTube video] and her January 18th [[video tape]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://disclose.tv/action/viewvideo/65806/Did_Asmaa_Mahfouz_trigger_the__Uprising_in_Egypt_/ |title=Did Asmaa Mahfouz Trigger The Uprising In Egypt? Video |publisher=Disclose.tv |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>, Mahfouz also rallied thousands of people to participate in the protests. The new [[Egyptian government]] that formed after the uprising requested to meet with her, but she declined.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.illumemag.com/zine/articleDetail.php?Egyptian-Youth-Inspired-by-Tunisian-Revolution-Hope-to--Follow-Suit-13452 |title=Thousands Fill the Streets in Egypt Protests |publisher=Illume |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref> On January 31, Asmaa Mahfouz, told Egyptâs [[Al-Mihwar TV]], about her decision to use Facebook to take action in Egypt before the Internet was jammed by the [[Egyptian Government]].<ref>{{cite web|author=http://memritv.org |url=http://www.memritv.org/clip/en/2785.htm |title=Asmaa Mahfouz, Organizer of the Demonstrations in Egypt, Talks About Her Decision to Use Facebook to Take Action |publisher=Memri |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref><ref>http://www.thememriblog.org/blog_personal/en/34047.htm</ref><ref>http://www.memritv.org/clip/en/2785.htm</ref>
  +   +
Asmaa was the among tens of thousands of protesters as they took to the streets bid to end President [[Hosni Mubarak]]âs 30 years of [[authoritarian]], single-party rule<ref>http://myrtus.typepad.com/myrtus/2011/02/meet-asmaa-mahfouz-the-girl-who-started-egypts-revolution.html</ref>.
  +   +
'''Asmaa was quoted as saying-'''
  +
<blockquote>âAs long as you say there is no hope, then there will be no hope, but if you go down and take a stance, then there will be hope<ref>http://myrtus.typepad.com/myrtus/2011/02/meet-asmaa-mahfouz-the-girl-who-started-egypts-revolution.html</ref>.â</blockquote>
